I came out for a weekend, and was excited to see he had a location on the strip.  I was greeted very graciously by the host staff and sat with my girlfriend at a nice table overlooking the casino.  Our server greeted us immediately and was very courteous.  we split a delicious caesar salad as an appetizer.  For our main course, my girlfriend had the salmon, which our server described to us was unique from Skuna in Canada.  She said it was delicious and ate every last bite.  I ordered a ribeye, which was off the menu.  It was cooked perfectly and definitely filled me up, but we had to try one of the desserts.  We split a chocolate fondant, which hit the sweet tooth perfectly.  The cocktail list was just as impressive as the dinner menu.  We look forward to our next trip back to Las Vegas, and dining with Daniel again!

Can't wait to dine here again! The food was amazing and reasonably priced for a quality strip restaurant. The dessert definitely made it into my top 5 desserts to date. White Chocolate Framboise! I can't stop thinking about it. The ambiance is very elegant and lively. Overall, just a pleasant dining experience. I noticed they do a lunch & dinner prefixe as well as a daily happy hour menu, which I can't wait to try.

Brunch Menu.

Crispy Duck Hash.
Croque Madame.
Belgian Waffle.
Freshly Baked Madeleines.

A bit disappointed that the Duck Hash & Belgian Waffle were not crisp at all. :( 
Still good though.
Would definitely order the Croque Madame & those light, crispy lemony Madeleines again. 
Hence, the extra star!

Magnifique!

Review for dinner.

While staying at the Venetian, my family ate a wonderful dinner at DB Brasserie. The appetizers and all our dinners were delicious. The wait staff was excellent, very attentive and helpful with the menu. We enjoyed dinner immensely. I would've given five stars, but I'm knocking off a star for the TV in the bar area. When I go to dinner in a nice restaurant, I don't want a big screen TV distracting from conversation and making it feel like a sports bar. Other than the TV, I would definitely eat here again.

Having visited every Daniel Boulud property in New York City, from the eponymous 3* dining room and its original 1* Café home to breakfast and brunch at Bistro Moderne and Sud, respectively, it was with great delight that I learned of the chef's return to Sin City - a new Brasserie helmed by former Marche Bacchus chef David Middleton scheduled for dinner with two friends, a tasting menu presumably pre-arranged by private dining manager Heidi Voskuil.  Every bit the bustling space suggested by its name, with close set tables and traditional heavy woods beneath the sexy glow of globed lighting, it was just after 6:30pm on Saturday when our party was seated and starting off with a stunning riff on the Bee's Knees our menu was confirmed...at least conceptually...though much of what followed was not exactly what was requested and much of it was marred by still-green service.  Setting aside small mistakes on sourcing and pronunciation as well as beverages spilled more than once plus an obvious miscommunication from front of house to back about the menu requested it was with a duo of Boulud's superlative terrines that we began and with the foie gras smooth as silk while the chicken and pork pate upped the ante with an earthy funk one can only hope for this program to expands; a "Bar Boulud" charcuterie program like that in Manhattan's theater district seemingly a perfect choice on The Strip.  Moving next to outsourced bread and salty butter before progressing into the one-two punch of garlicky snails followed by the best scallops I've had in recent memory as the restaurant filled to perhaps 80% capacity it was in our fourth course that things got interesting; the lightly seared lamb and its spicy sausage tender and delicious but served as our "main course" when my request had clearly delineated the duck as a 'must.'  Eventually served the confit after much hemming-and-hawing including the involvement of the Dining Room Manager suffice it to say that the crispy-skinned fowl is absolutely worth visiting (and perhaps fighting) for and finishing the evening with a glut of sweets plus a quintet of award-winning cheeses one can only hope the service can soon keep up with the kitchen...not only does Chef Middleton's cuisine warrant it, but so does the textbook Gateau Basque.

Do yourself a favor and remove this restaurant from your list!  By comparison, the former DB Brasserie in the Wynn was far superior to the new DB Brasserie in the Venetian. This version was bland and lacked personality.  Unless you are into stuffy, unattentive servers from France, then skip DB Brasserie.  I would be willing to bet that they won't make it to their second anniversary.

Phenomenal!!! Service awesome and food amazing.  Fun bistro with a great atmosphere.  Daniel is an amazing chef and I have been to a number of his restaurants in NY and he is simply amazing.  Service first class fun and talkative!  Drinks innovative and fun!  Doesn't kill your wallet either. Highly recommend

One word comes to mind when eating here....CORPORATE...hey the food is decent no doubt, but how about a little soul coming out of that kitchen...check out L'atelier at the MGM if you want to know what I mean....and what the F is the deal for the prices that are charged for cocktails here, I know it is a profit center for you guys but Daniel really- if you have a corporate charge card and are a wannabe from LA- this is your place...

We came here for my birthday on a Wednesday night and ordered 
1. Calamari - 15
2. Seafood linguini - 28
3. Steak frites - 36
4. Souffle - 15
5. Fat tire, gls - 7
6. Stella , gls- 7
7. Complimentary bread 
for $140.50 

- My gf made reservations a week ago. We were 10 minutes late for our reservation, but the hostess said no worries and gladly accepted us and sat us at a private table.
- Issouf, our server, was very personable and professional. He made sure that the visit was exceptional from start to finish. 
- He grew up in Paris so the theme of eating at a Paris restaurant, even though we barely ordered anything authentically French, was heightened. 
- He informed us on the specials. Recommendations on drinks, entrees, and desserts was presented to us very nicely. 
- The portions are small but enough for you to feel satisfied without feeling stuffed. You can always ask for more bread to fill your stomach, too. 
- Calamari was flaky. Sauce had a thai spice. Good appetizer. 
- Steak frites was great. Made medium. Tender. Comfort zone food. 
- Seafood linguini was made from scratch. Zesty flavor. Big chunks for shrimp. 
- Souffle came warm and fluffy. Sauce drizzled on top to make it fall. Tasted wonderful! Great finisher. 
- The pastry chef wrote happy birthday in cursive and Issouf gave us complimentary coffee for both of us. 
- Excellent choice for a special occasion!

The food here is good but I can't say the same for the service. I've celebrated a birthday here as well as somebody else's birthday.

I recommend the Duck Confit and Frenchie Burger. The steaks are alright. For dessert, get Le President and a Rocky Road Macaron. I love the popovers which is part of their bread service. 

However, the service is borderline rude. My friend called to confirm our reservation and that they were aware we were celebrating a birthday so we'd like something simple yet special like "Happy Birthday" written on the plate with chocolate and a candle. The response she got was "we already know it's her birthday." Wow! On behalf of my friend, I'd like to apologize for bothering whoever answered the phone as I'm sure she had more important and intellectual things to do than deal with customers. When we got to the restaurant, our server seemed like she was having a bad day. A friend had ordered her second glass of wine but she only got 1.5 glasses because the bottle ran out but the server said she'll get a new bottle to fill her glass - that didn't quite happen without grief. And when the dessert came, there was nothing "Happy birthday" about it - no chocolate writing, no candle.

I think when you have to deal with customers, you should be allowed to "call in bitchy" that way you can get your act right and not piss off paying customers.

Poor experience all around. My fellow diner's salad dressing was misplaced, and my salad didn't come altogether. Wanted an Arnold Palmer, but the server returned to say they're out of lemonade. Servers were confused about who was responsible for our table, and the restaurant was less than half full. Not what I expected.

I love their weekend brunch, I had the Crispy Duck Confit Hash and Blueberry Lemon Sundae. The duck was to die for and on top of that they offer a 30% discount for local which I found to be amazing especially given the location of this Daniel Boloud restaurant. Definitely coming back!

We went for restaurant week and this was a nice surprise. This is a very nice restaurant with great service and really good food. The bread basket at the start is too good! I had the melon gazpacho to start and it was lovely. I had the salmon for the entree: small portion yet very good. For dessert, I chose the 3 melon sorbet which was nice. My friend chose the chocolate bombe which was pretty cool to look at and tasted very good. Wine by the glass has a great selection with good pricing. The restaurant is on the expensive side, yet the food is delicious. Will definitely go back.
My 1st Dinner in Vegas on 9/11/14.  Elegant.  Great service.  I went with  3 other people.  Everyone was pleased with their entrees.

We stopped by during Thanksgiving afternoon hoping to catch the lunch prix-fixe.  Unfortunately since it was Thanksgiving, it was not available.  Instead, my kids shared the Turkey 3 course prix-fixe dinner.  My husband had the Linguini du Sud ($28) which had to be re-made due to being too salty.  After the fix, it was wonderful.  I had the seared salmon.  It was beautifully presented and a tad on the salty side.  However, the temperature was cooked to perfection.  At the end, the kids had a pumpkin pie as their 3rd course, and my husband and I shared a Grand Marnier Souflee ($15).  It was smaller than I had expected, however, it was delicious and even left a citrus and yummy after taste that I carried with me for some time.  Over all, the service was professional, but somewhat cold.  I enjoyed the atmosphere, but did notice that my husband and I (in our forties), were the youngest couple eating in the establishment.  This is not a trendy kind of place, but an over all nice brasserie with good food.  Was I wowed?  No, but I may have expected more since it was Daniel Boulud.

My girlfriend and I had a prix fix menu included in our package at the Venetian. We arrived at dinner for nothing but disappointment. We waited nearly 45 minutes for bread on a Monday night with the place practically empty. Our server was anything but friendly. Our first courses arrived 15 minutes apart. Her salad first and my French onion soup 15 minutes later. The coq au vin was terribly under seasoned and over braised. The dessert was okay but again our service was HORRIBLE. An hour and a half for 3 courses.....I had 9 courses at bazaar meat in SLS in an hour and 15 minutes......as a culinary grad this was extremely disappointing experience. For all those who ask, I did speak to a manager and explained how bad the food was and how horrible our server was. I ended up calling the concierge at the Venetian and received a  $95 credit. Honesty, your better off getting 4 courses at table 10 for $48 than this classic French American crap
Had beef tartare for appetizer. Very good, highly recommend . Main course: scallops, perfectly cooked, very flavorful. Dessert: soufflé and madeleines, very light and delicious. You should try these.
3.5 for brunch - beautiful space and good service .... Would be a 4 but my husband got a handful of bad mussels in his dish.

Food was awesome, service was not so great.  We ordered the cheese plate the wrong thing cane out we didn't realize just thought it was bigger  than we thought. The waiter  realized the error and mid bite he took it away. Now I realize we didn't order it but once we started on it we knew it couldn't be served and wondered why they didn't just  leave it for a good  service experience.  Great food,service might be why I wouldn't go there again.

Beginning to think its a thing with Vegas... They are slow to cocktails and bad with follow up service. Our waiter was superb, but we didn't he didn't tell us about the specials and the refills on water were less than speedy. The kicker... There were at least FOUR men in suits standing around looking important while the servers and bus boys busted their butts. 

So, then why the four star review? Because the food was excellent and that's really the point. The butter poached halibut may have been the best thing I tasted all week.
The drinks are a bit spendy but the service is very good. Friendly atmosphere and excellent appetizers.

Just OK, nothing special here. A mediocre Sidecar was how the meal started. Good though non-memorable French Onion Soup. Tasty, perfectly cooked Scallops with good creamed celery root, but sand or grit on two of the scallops. I wanted to love this place because it is a Boulud restaurant, but I found it unremarkable. There are better places to eat in Vegas. I will not be returning.

We went with a group of 8 people. 3 of us had to send our eggs Benedict back twice! It was cold and the whites were really, really runny. The second time it was a tad warmer, but all 3 plates were still runny. Then we just gave up and said forget it and that we don't want it. The server didn't apologize and kind of acted like it was normal to have food sent back twice! He didn't even get the manager for us. It wasn't even that busy. We had to ask for refills for the $20 bottomless mimosas. My friends that got Bloody Marys had to ask as well if they could even get the server's attention. 

Then when the bill came, he actually charged my friend that sent her meal back twice for 2 glasses of regular orange juice. We finally asked for the manager and told him the situation and he could have cared less. But he did take the OJ and the 3rd eggs Benedict off the bill and gave us a local discount since my friend is local. 

The others did enjoy the pastries plate The scraps of omelet my friend shared with me because I was starving was tasty too.

Disappointing but not because of the food and drink. Those were both very good. Saddened because they missed out on acknowledging a birthday and anniversary. We had made reservations a while back and mentioned this evening would have multiple celebrations and was noted at that time. No mention whatsoever tonight. Not making this statement because we were hoping for a free dessert or two but at least make us feel a little special that we celebrated at your restaurant???? We should have gone elsewhere... Probably won't be back because of this.

Attention to these types of details make or break a restaurant. They could learn from Mon Ami Gabi where this would have never happened. Service and attention to detail match the quality of the food there.

I'm also not the only one who has mentioned this in a review of DB.

This was a really cute French styled restaurant that we stopped into while bar hopping around the Venetian (it wasn't too far off from the hotel as I recall). The menu had some interesting options on it but sadly wasn't available as we were there too late and the kitchen was closed and only had time for a drink before we had to move on. The comfy chairs were a nice touch though and we relaxed for a bit with a good cocktail and conversation before moving on.

The menu has some unique items on it that caught my eye and warrant a second look next time through. The Moscow Mule I had was one of the best ones I've had in a long time so I would highly recommend!

This is a solid 4*. Again price point and expectations come into play.

We had the foie gras app. This is the cold version not the grilled. You get a nice piece of foie gras a couple of small pieces of toast, frieze salad and white radishes. The radishes were a wonderful touch that I used to clean my palate between bites of foie gras. The foie gras is rich and buttery.

We then had their take on a Cesar Salad. Simply put one of the best Casers ever. They did not drown it in dressing. The dressing had a wonderful anchovies' flavor (not over powering) and it was made with super fresh crispy greens. The shaved carrot and pine nuts added color and crunchiness. I like the pine nuts instead of the typical bread bites. 

Dinner was the spendy $62 steak. Grilled perfectly with sautéed oyster mushrooms on top and the creamed spinach that was came with the dish was not what I expected. Normally, I hate creamed veggies. The cream is usually too powerful and it's a soupy mess. This spinach was awesome. Even the wifey had some and she was very reluctant at first.

I came in to this new addition to the Venetian food scene with the highest of hopes. Daniel Boulude's triumphant return to Vegas is not without high expectations. I had, of course, read up on who was joining Chef Daniel's army of chefs and contributors and was astonished to learn of Chef Dave Middleton and Chef John Courtney's reunification. This phenomenal pair had already impressed the Las Vegas food scene at Marche Bacchus, an off strip locals spot, with their French nuances paired with a classy touch of modernity. But this time, they were in the big leagues, and they are privileged to compete under Chef Daniel's unyielding standard. No taste bud was left unturned. The artichoke velouté, coq au vin, and pistachio cherry were perfection and a true treat. The Tunisian inspired lamb, and an unexpected dish, the Thai calamarie, have such depth and take you through every sensation. Thank you Chef Daniel for your stylish return to our city, you do not disappoint. Chef Dave and his right hand, Chef John are representing you beautifully.

Did lunch with colleagues during the conference. DB is celebrated chef and his own brand. $25 lunch for 2 courses is not a bad deal. Atmosphere is quite pleasant, resembles Parisian brasserie. Service is friendly. Didn't think too much about shrimp cocktail appetizer, but filet sandwich was well executed. It was fast lunch in bar area, would like to do dinner there one day. I remember enjoying DB dinner in NYC.

Came here for happy hour. We ordered the cheese plate, oysters, salad and calamari. I thought everything thoroughly met expectations. The portions here are more substantial that most happy hours, which was nice. I wish that there was a tiny bit more variety, but overall very satisfied. I especially enjoyed the oysters-they were very fresh. 

Service was quick and friendly. I'm not sure if I would come back here for a real meal but it's definitely a winning spot for a light meal or snack!

Date Visited: 12/2/2016

Every year the No1DP goes to Vegas to attend a conference related to his industry. Since the conference and his hotel room are located in the Venetian|Palazzo complex he'll look for restaurants inside the complex for quick and full service dining. Three years ago he first found this place and loved it because it was one of the quieter fine dining places boasting a decent wine selection. On his second visit he took me on a wonderful date on the condition that I keep it off-record. Shortly before this most recent visit I read that DB Brasserie was to close as chef/owner Daniel Boulud wanted to focus on his other restaurants. I suggested we dine here one last time to bid the restaurant farewell. The No1DP agreed - he also wanted to introduce his mom to Vegas fine dining to break the ice.

VENUE: The closer you are to the "outside" the less privacy your meal will be, but in exchange it's one of the prime spots for people-watching inside the hotel complex. It is situated right along Restaurant Row that connects the Venetian and the Palazzo. Towards the back are tables and booth space. Despite being a brasserie I was able to have a conversation with the No1DP without having to clarify every other sentence. 

SERVICE: While our server was nice she did the bare minimum because she knew as well as we did about the restaurant closing. The restaurant gave off this sad vibe and was just living out its last days until its closure at the end of the year.

The No1DP and I had mules. They were served in regular glasses and were quite unremarkable. 

- Escargots (spätzle, wild mushrooms, hazelnuts, $15). Surprisingly this was my favorite dish. I haven't had escargot in years and I just loved the texture. It was quite earthy and I especially loved eating it with mushrooms. 
- Caesar Salad "Provencal" (tomato confit, basil pesto, rosemary croûtons, $9). No1DP's salad. He thought it was okay.
- Roasted Butternut Squash Soup (spiced crème fraÎche, toasted chestnuts, shaved apple, $12). The No1DP's mom's dish. She wasn't in the mood to eat very much so she got through half of her soup.
- Seared Diver Scallops (celery root & chestnut purée, trumpet royal mushrooms, apple pine nut gremolata, $39) No1DP loves his scallops so it was quite a statement for him to barely touch his plate. He says they were a tad overcooked.
- Crispy Duck Confit (braised kale, caramelized onions, white beans, $32). I was already getting full from eating escargot so I only had a few nibbles of my duck confit. Duck meat was soggy and not as tasty as excellent duck confit I had in San Francisco.

Boulud closed the space because he nor the hotel could settle on a concept for the space. The chef wanted to do casual French-American while the hotel, being one of the forefront hotels for Vegas luxury wanted something more upscale to compete with the other luxury hotels offering fine dining. The No1DP speculates that due to the changing demographic of Vegas travelers hotels want to bring in more bold, unique cuisine more suitable to younger people. What will replace this space will serve up Latin-American cuisine. 

Supposedly Chef Boulud hasn't given up on Vegas just yet, he just wants to find another hotel that is more willing to accommodate his vision. I look forward to what the chef comes up with, meanwhile this will give me more reason to try his restaurants in New York, specifically Daniel.

Decided to check this place out for an anniversary dinner. I sincerely feel we chose the wrong date to dine because there seemed to be some sort of event going on in the restaurant...on a Wednesday night. We made reservations for 9pm and had found out prior to coming that they offered happy hour at 10pm so it sounded like a good idea to have a few drinks after dinner. We were seated in a very small table for 2. The space was very limited but we were made felt better when we received a glass of champagne for our anniversary. They provided bread and butter. Our servers were very nice and attentive. We had a few appetizers and had flat iron steak and filet mignon with potato puree and roasted sprouts. It was good, but definitely have had better. The noise from the event was a deal breaker for us. We skipped the dessert and since our server made no mention of happy hour we decided to go out elsewhere for drinks. Feel like I came in here with high expectations due to the reviews, but was honestly nothing special. May be back in the future to give it another try.

Food was very good, better than I expected.  I just feel the location is not great.  Opens up to all the slot machines.  Very noisy.   Service was also a bit slow.  I enjoyed the meal, however nothing really special, and I can't imagine I would dine there again.

       I've been a fan of chef Daniel Boulud and I've been to every single restaurants he owns in New York City, as well as his former restaurant here in Las Vegas at the Wynn before. I was stoked to try this DB Brasserie.

      The space is gorgeous, spacious, elegant, and Frenchies in an Italian ispired Venetian of all hotels in Las Vegas. "db Brasserie is Chef Daniel Boulud's new contemporary French restaurant at The Venetian® Las Vegas. The menu stays true to Chef Boulud's signature French-American cooking and modern sensibility by offering updated brasserie classics, along with three of Boulud's signature burgers featured at his restaurants New York City. Market-driven dishes, using the season's best ingredients, and a selection of elegant desserts round out the menu." It was exactly how I would imagined it. 

       Greeted nicely by hostess Elda and Jairy, we were seated promtly with our private party. Our servers were attentive to our party. Pass Hor d'ourves were flowing out nicely and qutie a few more dishes of the night that we go to indulge. 

- PÂTÉ DE CAMPAGNE BOURGUIGNON, homemade pickles, country bread - Oh my goodness! 

- FOIE GRAS AU TORCHON rhubarb, turnips, pistachio, frisee - California banned foie, I got to order everything with Foie Gras in it. 

- HAMACHI CRU, eggplant cumin aigre doux, finger lime, harissa, shallot  - you wouldn't believe what a 3 Michelin Star French chef can do, ORDER IT.

- SAUMON AU CHOU, Savoy Cabbage, Horseradish, Maitake, Pork Belly, Radish, Poppy Seed - love. 

- CROQUE MONSIEUR, Warm Ham, GruyÈre and Béchamel Sandwich, CROQUE MADAME - Topped with a Farm Egg, I just had to order this, just because. 

- Crispy Duck Confit , swiss chard, turnip, trumpet royale mushrooms, onion rings - I can eat this dish ver and over. 

- "LE PRÉSIDENT"  Chocolate-Hazelnut Mousse Tart, Coffee Chantilly - delicious.

      We're glad that chef Daniel Boulud is back in town. This is a restaurant when I come here, I will gaurantee the food will be good, consistent, and exactly how I crave for these French dishes. 

        Chef  David Middleton executed chef Daniel Boulud 's vision well. I highly recommend it this place, good food, good wine list, unpretentious, and in a casual and comfortable setting. Service was excellent fromn start to finish, hat off to the management since DB Brasserie is still such a new spot! 

P.S. Inside the Venetian Hotel

I came here over New Years Eve weekend.  Full disclosure, I am not a huge fan of French food but since everyone else in my group wanted to try it. 

For appetizer we had the charcuterie platter and the chicken liver pate. Both were pretty good and nice to share. DB Brasserie has a signature French bread that is basically a hollow bread roll seasoned with peppers and cheese. It was really unique but delicous. 

I had the seafood linguine which was decent but not like earth shatteringly good. The pasta had a unique lemon and saffron taste to it which was delicious. 

The service left much to be desired though. The restaurant wasn't the least bit crowded but service was very slow!

All in all it was good food but i guess I expected something different from a place that was as upscale as this one was.

One of the best places for a steak dinner in vegas so far!  its pricey, but good!  My waiter was friendly and very attentive.  a perfect place for couples! My Steak was perfectly cooked, I ordered the french onion as a starter and it did not disappoint either!

I expected better from Daniel Boulad. Even though this restaurant is a cheaper version of his Micheln- rated restaurants, it doesn't give him an excuse to produce okay tasting food with okay quality.

Appetizers-
Classic French Onion Soup 13
Besides being too salty, the soup was decent. A ton of cheese (which I personally like). 

Pate de Campagne Bourguinon 18.
The best part was the toasted country bread. The pork pate was good, and everything together was decent. but nothing special. 

Terrine of Foie Gras 24.
Again, nothing special. It was okay. Expected more. 

Oysters 18.
3 East & 3 West Coast Oysters. The west coast oysters were super yummy and fresh. The east coast oysters were creamy and interesting. One of the appetizers I would recommend. 

Escargot Spatzle 18.
Another appetizer I recommend. With the mushrooms, garlic, and hazelnut, the flavors and texture combined so well together. Yum.

Entrees-
Sea Scallops, Creamed Cabbage, Beech Mushrooms, Bacon Lardon, Red Wine Shallots 30
The scallops were cooked perfectly. Slightly soft on the inside. These were good. 

Crispy Duck Confit, Swiss Chard, Turnip, Trumpet Royale Mushrooms
Onion Rings 36
Too salty. Onion rings added a nice touch and the duck was tender, but ease up on the saltiness.

Sea bass, Roasted Squash, Wild Rice, Toasted Hazelnuts, Romesco Sauce 38.
It was a good, normal sea bass. Nothing special about it. For the price you pay, definitely not worth it. 

Alaskan Halibut, Bean Fricassée, Rock Shrimp, Chorizo, Saffron Potato
Black Olive Sauce 40.
Their rock shrimp looks like it was frozen. Probaby was. Again, another average dish.

Short rib, Potato Fondant, Port Braised Shallot, Carrot Coulis. 36
Dry, chewy, not tender. Didn't even bother finishing it. Oh and salty....

Linguini de sud, Lemon Saffron Pasta, Clams, Shrimp, Shaved Bottarga, Sea Beans, Wilted Arugula 28
Saving the best for last... I was lucky I ordered this one. The linguini was perfect. Slight hint of lemon, a little bit of crunchy texture, delicious clams and shrimp.. Yum. One of the best linguinis I've had actually...

Service was good, but based on the price that everyone paid, this dinner was not worth it for the quality of food you get. Will not be back. I can see why this restaurant isn't michelin rated.

DB is a solid place to dine if you happen to find yourself in between The Palazzo and The Venetian. The restaurant itself is extremely inviting, the menu is attractive and the service was great. What else can be said?! Ordered the Steak and Frites and it was delicious, tasted very similar to  the French restaurants in Paris, mmmmm! They actually had Coravin wine by the glass which is not all that common and essentially allows the wine to be poured without displacing the cork. Made my Pinot taste delicious... Actually, the only reason that I'm subtracting a single star is because the server actually spilled the wine when he was attempting to pour using the Coravin process lol, resulting in a bit of my $35 per glass wine on the table cloth. Regardless, the overall dining experience was great and the food was awesome.

I've always enjoyed DB Brasserie every time I've come. I can't speak to their brunch, but my dinners have been great. The service is top notch, and I've never had a bad meal. Yes, they're on the strip, and it can be pricey, but that's the nature of the Vegas beast.

They do have a great happy hour twice each night. One early evening, and the other late, which I love. Mind you the prices aren't as cheap as off strip happy hours, but at least it's decent for the strip. The oysters on the half shell pulls the people in quickly, and if you arrive too late into happy hour, you could be out of luck. Another item I really like is the Thai calamari. They're beer battered with pickled Fresno peppers, kaffir lime, and cilantro. Add in a cold beverage or a glass of wine, and kick back to enjoy the people watching and the sounds of the busy casino.

I'm a fan--of the service! The bartender was hilarious! I can see how some people won't be receptive to a loud, comedic bartender in a fancy dining area, but he was great. He suggested the pumpkin ale--which I know is in season--but it was a good ale. I'm just not partial to ales with lots of hop.

My companions and I ordered a flatbread with bacon and cheese. It was good except for the fact that the flatbread was VERY thin--tortilla thin--instead of my usual BJ Brewhouse type expectations of a thick, chewy, warm flatbread. It was good just not enough to fulfill the appetite.

Other than that, there were no complaints for the place except that you can't expect happy hour time to come with a waiter/waitress even if you are sitting at a table by the bar. It will have to be the bartender.

Booked reservation on OpenTable for 3 people at 8:30 on a Sunday without issue.

We were running a few minutes late, so I called the restaurant to let them know, and they were fine with it.

After walking through the Venetian casino, you will find DB Brasserie nestled in a back corner with a prominently displayed "A" health rating.

We were quickly seated in what was about a half empty dining room, and it remained that way through our whole meal.  The ambiance is nice, comfortable seating, booths, tables, a long bar.  Water served without ice, how European.

The Cocktail Menu:
There is a good mix of inventive drinks here.  I personally had the Ex Pat, with a flavor that developed nicely as the vanilla and ginger infused ice ball melted into the straight bourbon.  I tried my friend's Manhattan, and it had nicely layered flavor.

Food:
I started with Escargot that were fried to a delicious, almost crispy chicken skin consistency.  There was also a mixture of shaved and fried garlic with normally cooked escargot.  The Foie Gras with cashew bread and a sweet chutney leveled with the salt and fat present very well.  For Main, I had the steak frites - crunchy, salty fries, perfectly medium rare flank steak.  Friend had the New York Strip cooked near rare, and it was a little tougher than it should have been in my opinion.  Dessert - Grand Marnier Souffle - delicately delicious with nice citrus notes.  "Black and White"- decadent and very rich.

General:
No salt and pepper on the table, which is not surprising.  Background music was a good mixture which specifically included a song by Disclosure.  Service was attentive.

We visited with the place only having been open around 6 weeks.  Overall, impressed, would come back, and not worry too much about getting a reservation on OpenTable.

Back again.  Server Robert made a convincing argument to try the prix fixe meal and the trout.  Thank you! The trout must have been fileted by a practicing surgeon because it was beyond beautiful. Poached perhaps in butter and then gently grilled and finished with a rich sauce of butter and raisin, it was a revelation. The wine buyer here has made DB a place to visit on a regular basis.  I love the casual vibe, but the five star kitchen and service are really striving to stand out here. A Must visit!

I visited DB last night. I was so looking forward to my visit, thinking back to Chef's previous restaurant in the Wynn Las Vegas. So, not so great. The setting is less than desirable being direct off the Casino, with all the noise and all the revelers that is Las Vegas. Poor location. Then there is a "lounge " area which is comfy, but very loud once filled. Not a good dining experience at all. I have no complaints about the quality of the food. Not too French, per se, but more "country French" a la Bocuse. Probably will not return.
The Cabernet is ok but the oyster and the calamari is wonderful if you are in those things.

Just had a wonderful dinner with my husband here. The service was excellent without being over done. It was nice to be able to enjoy our meal without having to "want" for anything and without being bothered by someone during each bite I took.The food was delicious but my absolute favorite was the Grand Marnier Soufflé for dessert!

DB Brasserie was great!  We went with a large group of 10 people, and had a fantastic meal.  I ordered the duck based on the waiters recommendation, and it was fantastic.  Crispy but also flavorful.  We had quite a few appetizers.  The only app that I would stay away from was the $80 seafood platter.  It was lobster and oysters, but was definitely overpriced and nothing special.

They also had a drink there that was very impressive.  It was basically a burbon poured over a vanilla infused ice cube.  As the ice melted, the drink got sweeter and became delicious.  That was worth going for, just in itself!

This restaurant was hugely disappointing considering the reviews we had read on various sites. Food was ok, but the service was atrocious. The waiter was less than attentive, drinks took forever to arrive and were highly overpriced (even for Vegas). But to reiterate, the service was the worse I have seen in Las Vegas, if not other places. In addition, our waiter seemed to enjoy his smart wit rather than helping us navigate the menu. 

As for pricing, I have not seen mark ups of 4-5 times on wine in quite a while. Totally unreasonable, again even by Vegas standards. 

Lastly, the ambiance is poor especially if you are located near the outside where you essentially feel like you are in the casino. Overall the restaurant itself is incredibly loud. Our party of four struggled to hear each other throughout the evening. I have been to Bouchon in the same Casino/Resort (Venetian) and it was quite a great experience. We were wanting to try something new but really regret it.

Bachelorette lunch with 9 girls, amazing service and good food

Duck Hash
- tender, flavorful, buttery from all the duck lard.  the potatoes soaked up all the flavor so it was all delicious

the best part of the meal was the free bread! it is SO FRESH, it just melts away like a pillow of floury goodness in your mouth!  don't be shy! it doesn't even need butter to be amazing.

my friends who had salmon rillettes claimed that it was salty

overall, a great meal at a reasonable price with perfect portions.  I wouldn't mind coming back here if I was invited

I had the iceberg and blue salad, it was very good, yet one would of been enough.

I had the flat iron steak and it was cooked to perfection and very very good.  Melted in my mouth.  

For dessert I had to have the GRAND MARNIER SOUFFLÉ.  It did not disappoint.  

Service was good, water always filled.

The menu online, not all was offered, which is why I piked the establishment, why I took off a star.

Daniel Bouloud has returned to the strip with classic French fare that is amazing. On top of that, Chef Vincent Pouesell had been added to the team. 

If you are going there, highly recommend the lunch, at a price of $25 for three courses on the strip you can't go wrong.

Awesome bar tenders and pretentious waiters, make this a case of duality. The decor is what you would expect of a modern French brasserie. But beer is not a focus here, the up sale is the wine and cocktails. Don't expect a warm welcome unless you look like you walked out of a fashion magazine. 

Shea, the bar tender, is awesome and makes this place more than bearable. And this man can make a drink. 

We had the Croque Monsieur (turned Madame) and the Frenchie Burger. The service needs help. The side salad was plain and bland. The focaccia is sour and comes with only a little butter. They won't let you have salt and pepper at the table, weird and annoying. It's not Bouchon. 

However, if you see a grand slightly rotund bar tender with short brown hair, hang out at the bar. He will entertain while briskly making miraculous nectar of heaven drinks. His name Shea. 

Stick to the bar, if Shea is there, and head for Bouchon for food.

Absolute worst brunch experience pretty much from the moment we walked in. We had a party of 8. We were 7 minutes late on our reservation and the hostess said "since you were late we had to move you to another table" uh!? We were late by 7 minutes!! Moving us is fine the table was still lovely but her attitude was crap! 

Bottomless mimosa/bloody mary's was a joke. My friends and I may of had 2 or 3 glasses that they filled halfway or a little more than halfway. Service was extremely slow and not very pleasant. 

3 people at our table order the eggs Benedict  that probably came right out of the refrigerator because that's how cold it was. When we sent it back the server didn't apologize and brought us out a "fresh" order which was runny and just disgusting. When we sent it back a second time again no apologize from our server. 

When we reviewed our bill it was incorrect and we had to ask for the manager after explaining our experience to him he said he was unaware of our issues and apologized. 

My friends that the omelet and the duck was pleased but overall it was not a good experience. Will not return.

In few words: the food is 4 stars, service is 2 stars. 
I was staying at the Venetian with my parents and we saw an extremely flattering and convincing commercial for this restaurant in our hotel room. We decided to dine here for dinner and I was extremely excited to have a paycheck's worth of an entree lol
Anywho, my father has a thick Spanish accent and the waitress had some difficulty understanding him. My dad has no shame in asking questions and the waitress would lean in and answer dramatically slowly, which I found to be rude and belittling. I usually step in and help translate or formulate the words my dad is trying to conceive, but they were both getting passively aggressive in their tone. My dad agreed that she was a bit hostile in explaining the different types of sauces that go with his $60 steak. 
A steak that he admits was one if the best he's ever had. My mom also enjoyed her prawn linguini, and I had a blast devouring my roasted chicken. My roasted chicken was a bit dry, but the bed of roasted vegetables added juices and jsatisfied my taste buds.
I worked with Heidi V to book a private cocktail reception and she was beyond helpful and accommodating. I'd recommend Heidi V and DB Brasserie anyone looking to book a private work event.

I was so looking forward to eating here again after the last stellar performance (see prior review), but I am sad to say that my great expectations only led to a greater letdown. 

The food:
Charcuterie board - prosciutto, duck rillettes, pate. While the duck rillettes were interesting, the other items were unimpressive both in quality and flavor. The standouts were the single cornichon and the mustard, both of which I wish there had been more of.

Steak frites - the steak was tough to cut and even tougher to chew. 

Short rib orecchiette - Really good flavor and loved the thin slices of short rib, but the noodles were fairly soggy and mushy in the mouth. 

Linguine du sud - noodles were al dente perfection and so deliciously lemony, but the arugula left a lingering bitterness that deterred you from the next bite. 

Can't remember what it was called, some kind of mushroom pesto pasta - was fine, and apparently not very memorabe


The service:
We were seated right away and greeted immediately. After that, however, with the exception of taking our order and bringing us our check, the waiter did not once stop by our table during the course of our nearly two-hour meal. He was also serving the large group near us, but he literally did not once stop by to ask how our meal was going. 


The ambiance:
Red Hot Chili Peppers and No Doubt - both musical favorites of mine, but maybe not so much during a pricey dinner at a white-table-cloth French restaurant.

The inconsistency in service and food, as evidenced not only by my varied experiences, but also by the all-over-the-board other reviews here, makes it hard to rave about this restaurant to others.
